pr_title: Following CALCITE-3769: Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ru…

timeline.message:
Following CALCITE-3769: Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset

* Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset, so there are 2
table implementations, the planner would choose the one with cheaper
cost
* Fix the cost estimation of BindableTableScan if there are no pushings
* Allows the Scannable table to have the EnumerableTableScan as impl

timeline.author: vlsi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -286,12 +286,11 @@ private static String schemaFor(String name, Class<? extends TableFactory> clazz
             + "      LogicalTableScan(table=[[STREAM_JOINS, PRODUCTS]])\n")
         .explainContains(""
             + "EnumerableCalc(expr#0..6=[{inputs}], proj#0..1=[{exprs}], SUPPLIERID=[$t6])\n"
-            + "  EnumerableHashJoin(condition=[=($4, $5)], joinType=[inner])\n"
-            + "    EnumerableCalc(expr#0..3=[{inputs}], expr#4=[CAST($t2):VARCHAR(32) NOT NULL], proj#0..4=[{exprs}])\n"
-            + "      EnumerableInterpreter\n"
-            + "        BindableTableScan(table=[[STREAM_JOINS, ORDERS, (STREAM)]])\n"
-            + "    EnumerableInterpreter\n"
-            + "      BindableTableScan(table=[[STREAM_JOINS, PRODUCTS]])")
+                + "  EnumerableHashJoin(condition=[=($4, $5)], joinType=[inner])\n"

timeline.message:
Following CALCITE-3769: Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset

* Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset, so there are 2
table implementations, the planner would choose the one with cheaper
cost
* Fix the cost estimation of BindableTableScan if there are no pushings
* Allows the Scannable table to have the EnumerableTableScan as impl

Following CALCITE-3769: Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset

* Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset, so there are 2
table implementations, the planner would choose the one with cheaper
cost
* Fix the cost estimation of BindableTableScan if there are no pushings
* Allows the Scannable table to have the EnumerableTableScan as impl
* For CsvTable and JsonTable in the example module, decoupling the logic
of runtime from Table#getRowType, so that these tables can implement as
ENUMERABLE convention(when there are no pushings)

Following CALCITE-3769: Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset

* Add BindableTableScanRule into the default ruleset, so there are 2
table implementations, the planner would choose the one with cheaper
cost
* Fix the cost estimation of BindableTableScan if there are no pushings
* Allows the Scannable table to have the EnumerableTableScan as impl
* For CsvTable and JsonTable in the example module, decoupling the logic
of runtime from Table#getRowType, so that these tables can implement as
ENUMERABLE convention(when there are no pushings)

timeline.bodyText: Instead of adding this code snippet, wouldn't be sufficient to just remove the factor 0.01d from the multiplier in line 253?
timeline.author: zabetak

replies.bodyText: No, we should give a preference though, so that the planner would choose BindableTableScan instead of EnumerabeTableScan, without this factor(0.01d), the BindableTableScan would never be choosed if the BindableTableScan has an expression and also pushings.
replies.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText: Aren't the factors f and p sufficient for achieving this?
replies.author: zabetak

replies.bodyText: Yes, the 0.01d factor would ensure that we choose the BindableTableScan if we have any pushing projects or filter. The EnumerableInterpreter has another 0.5 overhead of the input table.
replies.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText:
This is our current choice, the cost estimation is not that accurate and we would rather to give some preference.
For example, why the factor of EnumerableInterpreter  is 0.5 ?
replies.author: danny0405
